metadata.title: Robinson R22
aws::graph::propositions: # Robinson R22 Helicopter Information
Robinson R22 requires a special endorsement by a certified flight instructor in the US.
Robinson R44 requires a special endorsement by a certified flight instructor in the US.
The special endorsement requirement is due to the low-inertia rotor system.
The special endorsement requirement is due to a teetering main rotor.
SFAR 73 includes discussion and training on energy management.
SFAR 73 includes discussion and training on mast bumping.
SFAR 73 includes discussion and training on low rotor RPM (blade stall).
SFAR 73 includes discussion and training on low G hazards.
SFAR 73 includes discussion and training on rotor RPM decay.
Tip weights were added to the Robinson R22 to increase rotor inertia.
The small rotor of the Robinson R22 limits weight.
The first Robinson R22 sold was in October 1979.
The first Robinson R22 sold had serial number 003.
The first Robinson R22 sold had registration number N1010WR.
Pacific Wing and Rotor, Inc. purchased the first Robinson R22 sold.
Tim Tucker represented Pacific Wing and Rotor, Inc. in the purchase.
Tim Tucker later became a test pilot for Robinson.
Tim Tucker later became a chief instructor for Robinson.
Robinson R22 with serial number 001 crashed in the ocean during certification testing.
The crash of Robinson R22 serial number 001 was due to a failure of the casting.
The casting mates the tail rotor gearbox and stabilizing fins to the conical monocoque aluminum tail boom.
Robinson R22 with serial number 002 was used to complete the Federal Aviation Administration certification.

text:
Due to the specific training required by the low-inertia rotor system and a teetering main rotor, operation of the Robinson R22 or R44 in the US requires a special endorsement by a certified flight instructor. SFAR 73 includes discussion and training on energy management, mast bumping, low rotor RPM (blade stall), low G hazards and rotor RPM decay.  Tip weights were added to the R22 to increase rotor inertia, but the small rotor limits weight.
The first R22 sold, October, 1979, S/N 003, N1010WR, was purchased by Pacific Wing and Rotor, Inc., represented by Tim Tucker who later became a test pilot and chief instructor for Robinson. S/N 001 was crashed in the ocean during certification testing due to a failure of the casting that mates the tail rotor gearbox and stabilizing fins to the conical monocoque aluminum tail boom and S/N 002 was used to complete the FAA certification.
